title: Cat. 56  Untitled, 1947
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Untitled  
Vence, May 1947  
Pen and black ink on cream wove paper; 40.2 × 26.2 cm (15 3/4 × 10 3/8 in.)  
Signed and dated: H. Matisse Mai 47 (lower right, in pen and black ink)  
Inscribed: pour Monsieur Caditz / HM (lower left, in graphite); B 1 (lower right, in graphite, partially erased)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Clement and Marjorie Caditz, 2001.668

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">In the spring of 1952, the Art Institute of Chicago presented the major retrospective Henri Matisse, which included a number of works in the museum’s collection today. The exhibition attracted many visitors and renewed enthusiasm for the artist’s work. Among his admirers was Chicago businessman and art collector Clement C. Caditz, who, spurred by the exhibition, purchased a number of prints. What he truly desired, however, was a unique artwork, though he believed this to be beyond his means. Boldly, he decided to write to Matisse and request a drawing for the modest sum of fifty to one hundred dollars. In August, the artist obliged, but stated that it was an exception; “Please do not encourage your friends to make me a similar request,” he implored. Matisse’s generosity was trumpeted a month later in Time magazine (fig. 56.1) after Caditz shared his story with Chicago-based photographer and correspondent Arthur Siegel.

The untitled drawing, now in the collection of the Art Institute of Chicago, was one Matisse made in May 1947 while living in Vence. It is a portrait of a young woman created with pen and black ink and with no underdrawing. With an experienced hand and light touch, Matisse cleanly rendered her sparkling eyes, the graceful tilt of her head, and her light, round curls. The lines are minimal, evenly spaced, and show no signs of hesitation. These few deliberate marks enliven the entire sheet in such a way that the white paper appears luminous, adding a discernible weight to the composition.

The work has similarities to Jackie, a suite of ten drawings of the artist’s granddaughter Jacqueline Matisse, also made in Vence in 1947. The girls appear to be about the same age and the style of their pen-and-ink portraits is comparable. Confidently executed on the sheet with equally weighted lines, each work embodies the unique character of the model with just a few abbreviated marks. In the Jackie suite, essential elements that define the sitter’s persona, such as short hair, a pointed collar, and a small thin nose, are repeated from one drawing to the next with subtle differences. For Matisse, part of the importance of working in a series was the cinematic effect of capturing the passage of time (see cat. 48 and cat. 49 for a discussion of Matisse’s themed suites). In Jackie V (1947; fig. 56.2) for example, the sitter looks right, and in Jackie VII (1947; fig. 56.3), she looks left, chin resting on her fist. The Art Institute’s drawing is likely one of several sheets depicting a curly-haired young woman with a collared shirt, which may have been why Matisse agreed to Caditz’s request. In another pen-and-ink drawing from the series (1947; fig. 56.4), also made in May and on the same size of sheet, the sitter slouches slightly to the left, her cheeks and jaw widened due to the shifted perspective, but in the Art Institute’s drawing, the young girl sits upright, elongating her neck. Matisse’s clear observations of his subject are recorded with a resolute pen that captures the girl’s distinct visage and pleasant demeanor.  
Debora Wood

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse drew the portrait directly with a metal-nibbed dip pen and black ink, with no preliminary sketch. The smooth, well-sized, cream wove paper is well suited to pen-and-ink drawing, allowing for uninterrupted fluid lines. There is a faint fine line in the hair at upper left, which is a stray pen-and-ink mark.

Signed and dated: H. Matisse Mai 47 (lower right, in pen and black ink) (fig. 56.5).

Matisse drew using pen and black ink. Under microscope examination at 200× the ink appears semitranslucent with a warm, almost brown hue though it appears black to the naked eye. Black pigment particles suspended in the translucent ink are evident. Under ultraviolet light (254 nm) the ink appears very brown. There is no fluorescence evident on the recto or verso (fig. 56.6) under 254 or 365 nm. The ink used differs markedly from the glossy, black ink employed in other drawings.

The support is medium thick, smooth, cream wove paper. The fiber matrix contains occasional inclusions and colored fibers visible at 2×. Transmitted light shows a fine screen pattern. The top edge was unevenly trimmed. All other edges appear hand torn.

40.2 × 26.2 cm (15 3/4 × 10 3/8 in.).

The drawing underwent conservation treatment in 2002. At that time a strip of brown Kraft paper tape was removed from the center of the top edge on the verso. Yellow stains left by tape adhesive at the four corners were reduced. The drawing was humidified and flattened to reduce dents and planar distortions.

There are yellow adhesive stains remaining at the four corners. There are other yellow stains along the lower edge and one at the left edge, above center. The top edge was unevenly and jaggedly trimmed. The interior of the sheet has darkened slightly while the edges retain a whiter hue where they were protected from light exposure.  
Kristi Dahm

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Given by the artist to Clement C. Caditz (Oct. 7, 1912–Dec. 15, 2001) and Marjorie Caditz (née Marjorie Epstein, died May 9, 1978), Chicago, from Aug. 14, 1952.

Given to the Art Institute of Chicago, Dec. 27, 2001.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">“Exceptional Matisse,” Time 60, no. 11 (Sept. 15, 1952), p. 70 (ill.).

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscription  
Location: lower left  
Method: graphite  
Content: pour Monsieur Caditz / HM (fig. 56.7)

Number  
Location: lower right corner  
Method: graphite, erased  
Content: B 1 [partially erased] (fig. 56.8)

Inscription  
Location: lower left corner  
Method: graphite  
Content: ph (fig. 56.9)

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">See The Serf (cat. 3), Nude in a Folding Chair (cat. 8), Apples (cat. 24), Bathers by a River (cat. 25), Interior at Nice (cat. 30), Woman on Rose Divan (cat. 33), Woman before an Aquarium (cat. 34), Lemons on a Pewter Plate (cat. 39), and Daisies (cat. 47). The Matisse retrospective was curated by Alfred H. Barr and opened at the Museum of Modern Art, New York (Nov. 13, 1951–Jan. 13, 1952). It subsequently traveled to the Cleveland Museum of Art (Feb. 5–Mar. 16, 1952); the Art Institute of Chicago (Apr. 1–May 4, 1952); and the San Francisco Museum of Art (May 22–July 6, 1952). The exhibition was accompanied by a major publication, Alfred H. Barr, Jr., Matisse: His Art and His Public, which is still considered an essential study of the artist.

In the early 1950s, Matisse prints could be purchased for as little as ten dollars, but monumental print projects such as Jazz (1947; see number 8 in Book Checklist) and Florilège des amours de Ronsard (1948; see number 9 in Book Checklist) would have been outside what Caditz was willing to spend. Upon their release, Jazz sold for $375 and the deluxe edition of Ronsard sold for $500.

In a letter to Clement Caditz, Henri Matisse wrote: “Mais je vous prie de bien vouloir ne pas encourager quelq’un de vos amis à me faire une demande similaire car j’ai accepté votre proposition tout-à-fait exceptionnellement” (But I beg you please do not encourage your friends to make me a similar request for I accept your proposal quite exceptionally). Matisse to Caditz, Aug. 14, 1952, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Arthur Siegel, “Art: Exceptional Matisse,” Time 60, no. 11 (Sept. 15, 1952), p. 70. While the circumstances of the purchase and subsequent publicity are not entirely documented, it is likely that the story of Caditz’s acquisition circulated through his circle of industrial and metal fabrication business associates. Caditz owned Northern Metal Projects and had founded an international trade association for the metal stamping industry. Siegal was a photojournalist and commercial photographer who received many commissions from the metal industry and contributed images and writings to magazines such as Time, Life, and Fortune.

The first drawing was made in charcoal to establish the subject of the suite; it was followed by nine drawings in pen and black ink. All ten are reproduced in John Elderfield, The Drawings of Henri Matisse, exh. cat. (Arts Council of Great Britain/Museum of Modern Art, New York/Thames & Hudson, 1984), pp. 228–31, 277–78.

The Art Institute’s drawing is inscribed "B 1" and Tête de jeune fille is inscribed “B 3.” The inscriptions indicate that these works are part of a series of variations on a theme: “B” is the theme, and “1” and “3” are the drawings’ numbers within that theme.

This ink is similar to that used in another pen-and-ink drawing in the Art Institute of Chicago’s collection, Woman Seated at a Table with Fruit and Pitcher (July 1944; cat. 54).

Descriptions of paper thickness and texture follow the standard set forth in Elizabeth Lunning and Roy Perkinson, The Print Council of America Paper Sample Book: A Practical Guide to the Description of Paper (Print Council of America/Sun Hill, 1996).

Margo Rachel McFarland, conservation note, Apr. 17, 2002, object database, Art Institute of Chicago. Treatment slides are in the conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

According to the inscription by Henri Matisse and a letter from Matisse to Clement C. Caditz dated August 14, 1952, the artist gave this drawing to Clement at the collector’s request; photocopy of letter in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Deed of Gift signed and dated by Clement C. Caditz, Aug. 14, 2001; Committee to Accept Year-End Gifts meeting minutes, Dec. 27, 2001, p. 11; photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. The drawing was already in process as a gift on the date of Mr. Caditz’s death on December 15, 2001, although it was not officially accepted into the Art Institute’s collection until the meeting of the Committee to Accept Year-End Gifts on December 27, 2001.

“Ph” is an abbreviation for “photo,” indicating that the drawing was photographed. Wanda de Guébriant to Emily Ziemba, email correspondence, Apr. 6, 2017, photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 56 Untitled, 1947.

fig. 56.1 Arthur Siegel, “Art: Exceptional Matisse,” Time, Sept. 15, 1952, p. 70.

fig. 56.2 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Jackie V, Vence, 1947. Conté crayon on white paper, 52.5 × 40.2 cm (20 11/16 × 15 13/16 in.). Musée National d’Art Moderne, Centre de Création Industriell, Centre Pompidou, Paris, gift of the artist, AM 1730 D.

fig. 56.3 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Jackie VII, Vence, 1947. Conté crayon on white paper, 52.5 × 40.2 cm (20 11/16 × 15 13/16 in.). Musée National d’Art Moderne, Centre de Création Industriell, Centre Pompidou, Paris, gift of the artist, AM 1731 D.

fig. 56.4 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Tête de jeune fille, Vence, May 1947. Pen and black ink on paper; 40 × 26 cm (15 11/16 × 10 3/16 in.).

fig. 56.5 Detail of Matisse’s Untitled (May 1947) showing the artist’s signature. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2001.668.

fig. 56.6 Verso of Matisse’s Untitled (May 1947). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2001.668.

fig. 56.7 fig. 56.8 fig. 56.9 </section>
